facts.text: The appellant was a resident of Ratangarh in the Princely State of Bikaner outside British India.
On November 6, 1945, the appellant started a business in Calcutta, with accounts closing on April 9, 1946 (relevant accounting year).

On January 19, 1946, the appellant came to Calcutta with 11 ten thousand rupees notes and 158 one thousand rupees notes, which he encashed a few days later through Punjab National Bank under High Denomination Notes Order, total value Rs. 2,68,000.
Appellant credited Rs. 2,68,000 in books of Calcutta business as capital received from him.
Appellant explained notes came from his father who died in 1942.
Income-tax Officer held explanation not supported by books/documents, treated Rs. 2,68,000 as income from undisclosed business, taxable.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed appeal, held books/documents showed notes part of assets from father's death, deleted Rs. 2,68,000 from assessment.
Commissioner appealed to Tribunal, which allowed in part: Rs. 1,28,000 as undisclosed income, Rs. 1,40,000 as capital.

Appellant's adoptive father Mohanlal was partner in Manekchand Tarachand in Calcutta, left in 1906 with large sum (Rs. 6-7 lakhs), started Kaluram Mohanlal business till 1925-26, then retired to Ratangarh, died April 22, 1942.
Appellant succeeded to father's estate including the notes.
Appellant relied on Ratangarh books of account (father's then continued by appellant) showing numbers of ten thousand notes and existence of one thousand notes.
Tribunal found father wealthy, retired 1906 with Rs. 6-7 lakhs, started own business, had substantial moneys in Bikaner State Savings Bank 1926-1942, but doubted genuineness of Ratangarh books.

Reasons for doubting books: no Calcutta business books 1906-1926 produced; no entries of receipt from closed Calcutta business; books only record bank transactions and accommodation loans to relatives; numbers of ten thousand notes in loan entries; incomplete record 1926-1942.
Tribunal found from 1926-1945, only source of income was bank interest; appellant had Rs. 8-10 lakhs in bank ~1945, impossible to have another 7 lakhs in notes.
Appellant assessed as non-resident British subject for 1946-47.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Denomination Notes of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed were part of assets received from father or undisclosed income.
Whether Tribunal's finding that Ratangarh books not genuine is sustainable, or based on no evidence/unreasonable view.
Whether even if income, taxable without finding accrued in British India as non-resident.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's finding that notes not from father unsustainable; Ratangarh books prove notes existed in father's lifetime; AAC correctly accepted books genuine and father's business history.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mehta Parikh & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax (court entitled to intervene if no evidence or unreasonable view)

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's estimation of uninvested cash and sources speculative.
As non-resident, cannot be taxed without finding income arisen/accrued in British India.

respondent_arguments.text: Notes represent concealed profits liable to tax (ITO view); books not genuine.

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court does not reassess evidence or come to own conclusion; intervenes only if Tribunal acted without evidence or unreasonable view (per Mehta Parikh).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal's reasons for doubting Ratangarh books (no Calcutta books, no closure entries, limited scope, etc.) are reasonable and supported by evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal's estimation of cash holdings and sources may be speculative but was a concession to appellant, not affecting core finding that notes not proved from father.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gave benefit of Rs. 1,40,000 as capital though strictly not entitled.

court_reasoning.text: Non-resident point not raised earlier, cannot be allowed now.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding that appellant failed to prove notes from father's estate is reasonably possible and sustained; Rs. 1,28,000 taxable as undisclosed income.
Supreme Court will not interfere with Tribunal's factual findings unless perverse.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mehta Parikh & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for Supreme Court intervention in factual findings of Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave to appeal from Tribunal judgment.

statutes_cited.name: High Denominations Notes Order
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions under which notes were encashed.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Tribunal's judgment upholding Rs. 1,28,000 as undisclosed income dismissed; Tribunal's findings on evidence sustained as reasonable.

key_quotes.text: "The Court would be entitled to intervene if it appears that the fact finding authority has acted without any evidence or upon a view of the facts, which could not reasonably be entertained..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test from Mehta Parikh for interference with Tribunal findings.

key_quotes.text: "It is not the practice of this Court to do so." (reassess evidence)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Supreme Court's role in factual appeals.

key_quotes.text: "We are unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal... are unfounded or that there was no evidence to support the view that the Tribunal took."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds Tribunal's rejection of books' genuineness.
